[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: SourceCoverage::execute()] [Panic on Type Mismatch] At line 124, the code panics with 'Should all be modules' if a non-Module unit is encountered - can an attacker craft a package structure that triggers this panic during coverage analysis, causing denial of service? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: SourceCoverage::execute()] [Unreachable Code Path] At line 132, 'unreachable!' assumes all root modules are CompiledUnit::Module - could compiler bugs, race conditions, or package corruption cause this assumption to be violated, triggering an abort that crashes the coverage tool? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: SourceCoverage::execute()] [ANSI Escape Injection] When color is set to ColorChoice::Always or Auto at line 102, does output_source_coverage() at line 137-138 properly validate that ANSI color codes cannot be injected through source code content, module names, or coverage data to execute terminal commands or obfuscate malicious code? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: SourceCoverage::execute()] [Source File Disclosure] If compute_source_coverage() at line 136 fails to validate that source_path is within the package boundary, can an attacker trick the tool into displaying coverage for system files, framework internals, or other packages' source code? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: SourceCoverage::execute()] [Coverage Map Poisoning] Can multiple test runs with different coverage patterns cause SourceCoverageBuilder at line 135 to produce incorrect or inconsistent source coverage displays that mislead developers about actual code coverage? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: CoveragePackage::execute()] [Serialization Bypass] Does execute_serialized_success() properly serialize errors and results, or can attackers craft inputs that cause serialization failures to be silently ignored, hiding coverage generation errors from users? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Function: CoveragePackage::execute()] [Async Safety] Since the execute() method is async, are there any race conditions or concurrency issues when multiple coverage commands run simultaneously on the same package, potentially corrupting shared state or file system resources? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Global] [Compiler Version Downgrade] Can an attacker force the coverage tool to use an older, vulnerable Move compiler version through move_options configuration, then exploit known compiler bugs to generate malicious bytecode that appears to have legitimate coverage data? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Global] [Package Path Injection] Across all three coverage commands (Summary, Source, Bytecode), can the package path from MovePackageOptions be manipulated to process coverage for system directories, other users' packages, or network shares, causing unauthorized access or information disclosure? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Global] [Symlink Attack] Can attackers use symbolic links in the package directory structure to cause the coverage tool to read or write files in unintended locations, potentially overwriting important files or exfiltrating data through coverage reports? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Global] [Test Code Execution] Since coverage is generated from test runs, can malicious test code exploit the coverage tool's file I/O operations (reading source, writing reports) to escape the test sandbox and perform unauthorized operations on the host system? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/move_tool/coverage.rs] [Global] [Coverage Data Tampering] Can an attacker pre-generate a malicious .coverage_map.mvcov file with fabricated execution counts that make malicious code appear well-tested, deceiving code reviewers and security auditors about the actual test coverage?
